Award.AwardTitle: Integrating Evolution and Development of Novelty and Diversity through the Study of Horned Beetles
Award.AbstractNarration:
Biologists have learned a great deal about the developmental and genetic changes that are necessary to facilitate gradual evolutionary modifications. For instance, much is known about the genetic and developmental basis that enable legs or wings to become longer, or eyes to become more efficient in a given environment. However, little remains known about how major complex traits, such as legs, wings or eyes, originate in the first place. What does it take to evolve the first limb, or wing, or eye, from a limbless and blind ancestor?

This research investigates the origin and diversification of novel traits using the unique, diverse and morphologically spectacular horns of beetles as focal traits. Beetle horns are produced in body regions in which other insects do not produce outgrowths, are highly variable in shape and size, and endow their bearers with an ecologically important function: a weapon to be used in combat between rival males over females. Beetle horns thus offer an outstanding opportunity to investigate the genetic and developmental means by which novel traits come into being and are elaborated upon as a group of organisms diversifies.

Specifically, this research uses molecular genetic and developmental approaches to investigate the regulation of growth, shape, and positioning of traditional appendages (such as legs or wings) and recently evolved, novel appendages (such as horns). In doing so, this research aims to identify the degree to which innovation and diversification in nature are enabled by novel genes and developmental pathways, or the re-use and modification of existing genes and pathways, or combinations of these two alternatives. As such it addresses a fundamental, unresolved question in evolutionary and developmental biology: how novelty can arise in nature from within the confines of ancestral variation.

Lastly, this research interfaces tightly with several educational and outreach efforts. (1) Using a collaboration with a local children's museum for science, health and technology this research will help provide training and educational resources in insect biology to approximately 180 local and regional K-12 teachers over the course of 3 years. (2) This research will help train at least 8 young scientists (6 undergraduate students, 1 graduate student, 1 postdoc) in intensive interdisciplinary research. (3) Lastly, it will facilitate educational outreach by helping recruit 6 high school teachers and 6 minority high school students for summer research immersion and introduce them to research in development, evolution, and ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The origin of complex, novel traits is among the most intriguing and enduring questions in evolutionary biology. On one hand Darwin's theory of evolution is based first and foremost on descent with modification: everything new, ultimately, has to come from something old. On the other, we are captivated by complex novel traits precisely because they lack obvious correspondence to preexisting traits. Where then and how do novel traits - the first eye, the first wing, the first feather - originate? In this set of studies we addressed these and related questions by studying a class of traits that is novel, diverse, ecologically important, and experimentally accessible: the horns of scarab beetles.

Beetle horns combine several characteristics that make them outstanding models for integrating diverse perspectives on the evolution of novel, complex traits (1) Beetle horns are major structures and provide their bearers with an important new function: a weapon used in male-male combat. (Fig. 1). (2) Beetle horns are remarkably variable, both within and between species. (3) Beetle horns are a true novelty, i.e. they are not simply modified antennae or mouthparts. (4) Beetle horns are influenced by both genetic and environmental factors. (5) Lastly, substantial experimental tools exist to investigate genetic, genomic, and developmental aspects of innovation in these organisms.  

Over the life time of this award we have been able to show that many important and novel aspects of beetle horn development have been made possible over evolutionary time through the re-use of pre-existing developmental processes that acquired novel or additional functions. For example, (a) horns need to be properly positioned on the head in order to be functional. We find that genes normally used in embryos to instruct the formation of the brain and head of nearly all animals have been re-used in horned beetles specifically to be active again in much later developmental stages to help induce and position horns on the head.  Similarly (b), horns often show extraordinary responses to feeding conditions, similar to weapons and ornaments in many other organisms. Optimal feeding results in supersized horns, suboptimal feeding in rudimentary development. We find that two pathways that function as switches in other aspects of development of virtually all animals (one distinguishes what will become the front and back of many body parts, the other separates between male and female versions of the same trait) have been re-used in horned beetles to operate as nutrition-responsive switches, promoting or inhibiting horns, respectively, depending on circumstances. These and several other examples discovered through this work provide important case studies in support of a phenomenon of increasingly broader significance in biology - the role of re-use and co-option of pre-existing features in the assembly of novel traits.  All results have been published in high ranking, peer reviewed journals, and all data have been made available in open access data repositories.

At the same time this award enabled several significant training and educational efforts:  (1) Six postdoctoral researchers, 8 graduate students, and over 20 undergraduate students received training in interdisciplinary biology. (2) Seven teacher-training workshops were carried out, introducing 135 K-12 teachers to newly developed teaching modules designed to enhance Indiana Science Teaching Standards. A subset of teaching modules have now been broadly institutionalized in South-Central Indiana thanks to the opportunities provided by this award. (3) Three summer programs directed by the awardee and executed every summer over the life time of this award enabled over 250 minority High School students to experience a progressively deeper introduction into the life sciences and independent mentored research. These so called James Holland Programs identify high performing minority students in early High School grades across Indiana and neighboring states, then support and mentor these students until they are accepted into college scholarship programs. This approach, developed by the awardee, has recently become institutionalized at Indiana University and will continue beyond the life time of this award.
